content.webTitle: Janay Rice: NFL chief 'lied' about knowledge of elevator incident

fields.headline: Janay Rice says Roger Goodell 'lied' about knowledge of elevator assault
fields.bodyText: Janay Rice has accused the National Football League of seeking to protect itself by giving an indefinite suspension to her husband, the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice, who was arrested in February after punching her in an elevator. She also said the NFL commissioner, Roger Goodell, lied when he said her husband had been “ambiguous” about the elevator incident, which occurred at a casino in Atlantic City. Rice’s suspension, which was handed out in September after he had been given an initial and much-criticised two-game ban, was overturned on appeal on Friday. A former federal judge accepted the player’s contention that he had been wrongfully punished twice, having told the truth about the event throughout the NFL’s disciplinary protest. Without a team after the Ravens released him, he is now free to play in the NFL this season. “I know for a fact that Ray told the honest truth that he’s been telling from February,” Rice said in an interview with the Today Show’s Matt Lauer broadcast on Monday. Rice has repeatedly defended her husband since a video released in February showed her then fiance dragging her from the elevator. In September, TMZ released a video of him punching her inside the elevator. After the release of the second video enflamed debate over how the NFL treated cases of domestic abuse involving its players, Goodell increased Rice’s punishment. Goodell has come under pressure over whether the league knew of and viewed the full video of the incident before it handed Rice his initial two-game ban. The commissioner has said he had not seen the full tape. Speaking to NBC, Janay Rice said she thought the NFL was trying to defend itself from criticism by changing her husband’s punishment. “I think they did what they had to do for themselves,” she said. Rice said her husband had never hit her before the elevator incident, which occurred a month before they married, and has not abused her since. “He knows what he would have to deal with, you know, if this was something,” Rice said. “You know, I’m not going to sit there in silence and let something happen to me – and God forbid, in front of my child, just like, let it happen? There’s no way.” She also discussed the chances that an NFL team would be willing to sign her husband. Such a deal would need a team “to look past this situation, which I know is going to be hard”, she said. “But at the end of the day he’s a football player and that’s what they should be really focused on because he’s proven himself as a football player for seven years. There’s never been a question on what he can do on the field.” Rice, 27, is a three-time Pro Bowl selection. He was part of the Baltimore team which won Super Bowl XLVII. He was charged with felony aggravated assault, before being accepted into a pretrial intervention program that could result in the charge being expunged from his record. Last week, ESPN released Janay Rice’s account of the night of the elevator incident and its aftermath, based on an interview with reporter Jemele Hill. “I still find it hard to accept being called a ‘victim’,” she said. “I know there are so many different opinions out there about me – that I’m weak, that I’m making excuses and covering up abuse – and that some people question my motives for staying with Ray. “However, I’m a strong woman and I come from a strong family. Never in my life have I seen abuse, nor have I seen any woman in my family physically abused.” The extensively trailed NBC interview, also with Ray Rice, was scheduled to be broadcast on Monday and Tuesday.
